I have a few more questions about VerusIDs. How do they handle changes to the controlling addresses or single/multi-sig properties?

**AI Assistant:**
When the controlling addresses or single/multi-sig properties of a VerusID are changed, all future spends of UTXOs sent to that identity will follow the updated spend conditions and be subject to the updated keys. This ensures that the identity remains flexible and adaptable to changing needs.

**AI Assistant:**
Yes, VerusIDs are resistant to quantum attacks with known algorithms. Additionally, Verus is integrating a quantum secure signature scheme, which will make it possible to change an ID and have all funds sent to it made retroactively quantum resistant. This future-proofs Verus against potential quantum threats.

**User:**
What else can VerusIDs be used for besides sending and receiving funds?

**AI Assistant:**
VerusIDs can also be used to publish ID->destination address mappings on other blockchains. However, only the Verus ecosystem has the ability to revoke, recover, or inherit funds in existing UTXOs. This feature expands the versatility of VerusIDs beyond just transactions.

**User:**
I'm curious about the underlying nature of the VerusID protocol. What's its nature?

**AI Assistant:**
The VerusID protocol is fully decentralized, allowing anyone to create an ID and have complete, self-sovereign control over it without permission. All costs to create an ID go to miners, stakers, and ID referrers. This decentralized approach ensures that VerusIDs are community-driven and not controlled by a central authority.

**User:**
One last question: what is the revocation authority in a VerusID, and what is its purpose?

**AI Assistant:**
The revocation authority in a VerusID is an authority that has the permission to revoke the identity. By default, this authority is the identity itself. If the revocation authority revokes the identity, it creates a valid transaction that, once mined into a block, prevents the identity from being used to spend or sign until it is recovered, effectively freezing all of its funds. This can be useful in cases such as key theft.

How do VerusIDs handle changes to the controlling addresses or single/multi-sig properties?

When the controlling addresses or single/multi-sig properties of a VerusID are changed, all future spends of UTXOs sent to that identity will follow the updated spend conditions and be subject to the updated keys.

### Quantum-ready friendly crypto-addresses on the worldwide Verus network
VerusIDs can be used to receive and send funds, which are controlled by the single or multi-sig addresses specified in the identity itself. If these controlling addresses or the single or multi-sig properties are changed, which can be done by the controller of the identity, all future spends of UTXOs sent to that identity follow the updated spend conditions and are subject to the updated keys. Although Verus 0.6.0 does not include quantum resistant signatures for transactions, VerusIDs are themselves resistant to quantum attack with known algorithms, and we have already started to integrate a quantum secure signature scheme, which we expect to activate on mainnet early next year. When that is available, it will be possible to change an ID and have all of the funds sent to it made retroactively quantum resistant. Verus IDs can also be used to publish ID->destination address mappings on other blockchains, but only the Verus ecosystem has the ability to revoke, recover, inherit, funds in existing UTXOs.### Fully Decentralized Protocol
Anyone can create one and have complete, self sovereign control over it without permission to do so. All costs to create an ID go to miners, stakers, and ID referrers. VerusIDs are:- **Revocable** -- each ID includes a revocation authority, which defaults to the identity self, and which has the permission to revoke the identity, which creates a valid transaction that, once mined into a block, prevents the identity from being used to spend or sign until it is recovered, effectively freezing all of its funds, for example, in the case of key theft.
